Iron Deficiency Anemia.text: Hemoglobin synthesis is impaired in IDA
Anemia develops despite increased erythroid lineage in bone marrow
Hypochromia and microcytosis of circulating RBCs due to inadequate hemoglobin production
Menstruation is most common cause in teenage girls and women of child-bearing age
Increased need for iron in growing children and during pregnancy is most common cause of IDA worldwide
Malnutrition due to reduced intake in vegetarians/vegans and older adult populations
Malabsorption secondary to parasitic infections, gastric bypass or duodenal surgeries, chronic inflammatory diseases of intestines, and celiac disease
Chronic blood loss from gastrointestinal tract, such as neoplasms and dialysis; medication, such as aspirin and NSAIDs
Blood donation may also contribute to IDA

Iron-Refractory Iron Deficiency Anemia.text: Autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation inTMPRSS6gene, which codes for transmembrane protease, serine 6, a.k.a. matriptase-2
Matriptase-2 inhibits signaling pathway that activates hepcidin and leads to high hepcidin level
Loss-of-function mutation leads to constitutively high level of hepcidin, thus blocking intestinal iron absorption and also limiting iron release from hepatocytes and macrophages

Incidence.text: Globally, estimated prevalence is 50% in preschool children, 42% in pregnant women, 30% in nonpregnant women
Prevalence in resource-rich countries is 2-5% in adult men and postmenopausal women, ~ 10% in women of child-bearing age, much higher in hospitalized patients

Presentation.text: Insidious onset, chronic, often asymptomatic
Fatigue, pallor, weakness, tachycardia, dyspnea on exertion
Difficulty in concentrating
May cause decreased cognitive performance and developmental delay in childrenImpairments may be persistent after resolution of IDA

Presentation.text: May predispose patient to infections
May precipitate heart failure
May result in longer hospital stay and poorer clinical outcome
Severe anemia in pregnant women may result in preterm labor, low birth weight, and increased mother and baby fatality rate
Pica (craving and consumption of ice and nonfood items), restless leg syndrome, esophageal webs, deterioration of cognitive function can occur
Other classic symptoms, such as koilonychia (spoon nails), glossitis, or dysphagia, are not common in resource-rich countries
